segment.source: Frequently asked questions
segment.target: Frequently asked questions

segment.source: FAQ about UWP on Xbox.
segment.target: FAQ about UWP on Xbox.

segment.source: Frequently asked questions
segment.target: Frequently asked questions

segment.source: Things not working the way you expected?
segment.target: Things not working the way you expected?

segment.source: Look through this page of frequently asked questions.
segment.target: Look through this page of frequently asked questions.

segment.source: Also check out the Known issues topic and the Developing Universal Windows apps forum.
segment.target: Also check out the Known issues topic and the Developing Universal Windows apps forum.

segment.source: Why are my games and apps not working?
segment.target: Why are my games and apps not working?

segment.source: If your games and apps are not working, or if you don’t have access to the store or to Live services, you are probably running in Developer Mode.
segment.target: If your games and apps are not working, or if you don’t have access to the store or to Live services, you are probably running in Developer Mode.

segment.source: You can tell you’re running in Developer Mode if you select Home and you see a big Dev Home tile on the right side of your screen, instead of the usual Gold/Live content.
segment.target: You can tell you’re running in Developer Mode if you select Home and you see a big Dev Home tile on the right side of your screen, instead of the usual Gold/Live content.

segment.source: If you want to play games, you can open Dev Home and switch back to Retail Mode by using the Leave developer mode button.
segment.target: If you want to play games, you can open Dev Home and switch back to Retail Mode by using the Leave developer mode button.

segment.source: Why can’t I connect to my Xbox One using Visual Studio?
segment.target: Why can’t I connect to my Xbox One using Visual Studio?

segment.source: Start by verifying that you are running in Developer Mode, and not in Retail Mode.
segment.target: Start by verifying that you are running in Developer Mode, and not in Retail Mode.

segment.source: You cannot connect to your Xbox One when it is in Retail Mode.
segment.target: You cannot connect to your Xbox One when it is in Retail Mode.

segment.source: You can simply check this by pressing the Home button and looking for the Dev Home tile on the right side of your screen.
segment.target: You can simply check this by pressing the Home button and looking for the Dev Home tile on the right side of your screen.

segment.source: If the tile is not there, but instead you see Gold/Live content, you are in Retail Mode.
segment.target: If the tile is not there, but instead you see Gold/Live content, you are in Retail Mode.

segment.source: You need to run the Dev Mode Activation app to switch to Developer Mode.
segment.target: You need to run the Dev Mode Activation app to switch to Developer Mode.

segment.source: For more information, see Fixing deployment failures later on this page.
segment.target: For more information, see Fixing deployment failures later on this page.

segment.source: How do I switch between Retail Mode and Developer Mode?
segment.target: How do I switch between Retail Mode and Developer Mode?

segment.source: Follow the Xbox One Developer Mode Activation instructions to understand more about these states.
segment.target: Follow the Xbox One Developer Mode Activation instructions to understand more about these states.

segment.source: How do I know if I am in Retail Mode or Developer Mode?
segment.target: How do I know if I am in Retail Mode or Developer Mode?

segment.source: Follow the Xbox One Developer Mode Activation instructions to understand more about these states.
segment.target: Follow the Xbox One Developer Mode Activation instructions to understand more about these states.

segment.source: You can simply check this by pressing the Home button and looking at the right side of the screen.
segment.target: You can simply check this by pressing the Home button and looking at the right side of the screen.

segment.source: If you are in Developer Mode, you will see the Dev Home tile on the right side.
segment.target: If you are in Developer Mode, you will see the Dev Home tile on the right side.

segment.source: If you are in Retail Mode, you will see the usual Gold/Live content.
segment.target: If you are in Retail Mode, you will see the usual Gold/Live content.

segment.source: Will my games and apps still work if I activate Developer Mode?
segment.target: Will my games and apps still work if I activate Developer Mode?

segment.source: Yes, you can switch from Developer Mode to Retail Mode, where you can play your games.
segment.target: Yes, you can switch from Developer Mode to Retail Mode, where you can play your games.

segment.source: For more information, see the Xbox One Developer Mode Activation page.
segment.target: For more information, see the Xbox One Developer Mode Activation page.

segment.source: Will I lose my games and apps or saved changes?
segment.target: Will I lose my games and apps or saved changes?

segment.source: If you decide to leave the developer preview program, you might have to do a factory reset, which will erase all the content on your console.
segment.target: If you decide to leave the developer preview program, you might have to do a factory reset, which will erase all the content on your console.

segment.source: If that happens, you will have to reinstall all the games and apps.
segment.target: If that happens, you will have to reinstall all the games and apps.

segment.source: As long as you were online when you played them, your saved games are all saved on your Live account cloud profile, so you won’t lose them.
segment.target: As long as you were online when you played them, your saved games are all saved on your Live account cloud profile, so you won’t lose them.

segment.source: How do I leave the developer preview?
segment.target: How do I leave the developer preview?

segment.source: See the Xbox One Developer Mode Deactivation topic for details about how to leave the developer preview.
segment.target: See the Xbox One Developer Mode Deactivation topic for details about how to leave the developer preview.

segment.source: I sold my Xbox One and left it in Developer Mode.
segment.target: I sold my Xbox One and left it in Developer Mode.

segment.source: How do I deactivate Developer Mode?
segment.target: How do I deactivate Developer Mode?

segment.source: If you no longer have access to your Xbox One, you can deactivate it in Windows Dev Center.
segment.target: If you no longer have access to your Xbox One, you can deactivate it in Windows Dev Center.

segment.source: For details, see the Deactivate your console using Windows Dev Center section in the Xbox One Developer Mode Deactivation topic.
segment.target: For details, see the Deactivate your console using Windows Dev Center section in the Xbox One Developer Mode Deactivation topic.

segment.source: I left the developer preview using Windows Dev Center but I’m in still Developer Mode.
segment.target: I left the developer preview using Windows Dev Center but I’m in still Developer Mode.

segment.source: What do I do?
segment.target: What do I do?

segment.source: Start Dev Home and select the Leave developer mode button.
segment.target: Start Dev Home and select the Leave developer mode button.

segment.source: This will restart your console in Retail Mode.
segment.target: This will restart your console in Retail Mode.

segment.source: Can I publish my app?
segment.target: Can I publish my app?

segment.source: Publishing for apps will be available through Dev Center later in the year.
segment.target: Publishing for apps will be available through Dev Center later in the year.

segment.source: UWP apps created and tested on a retail Xbox One will go through the same ingestion, review, and publication process that Windows conducts today, with additional reviews to meet today’s Xbox One standards.
segment.target: UWP apps created and tested on a retail Xbox One will go through the same ingestion, review, and publication process that Windows conducts today, with additional reviews to meet today’s Xbox One standards.

segment.source: Can I publish my game?
segment.target: Can I publish my game?

segment.source: You can use UWP and your Xbox One in Developer Mode to build and test your games on Xbox One.
segment.target: You can use UWP and your Xbox One in Developer Mode to build and test your games on Xbox One.

segment.source: To publish UWP games you must register with ID@XBOX.
segment.target: To publish UWP games you must register with ID@XBOX.

segment.source: ID@XBOX provides developers full access to Xbox Live APIs for their games, including Gamerscore and Achievements, as well as the ability to take advantage of multiplayer between devices, cloud saves, and all the features of Xbox Live on Xbox One.
segment.target: ID@XBOX provides developers full access to Xbox Live APIs for their games, including Gamerscore and Achievements, as well as the ability to take advantage of multiplayer between devices, cloud saves, and all the features of Xbox Live on Xbox One.

segment.source: ID@XBOX can also provide access to Xbox One development kits for games that require access to the maximum potential of the Xbox One hardware.
segment.target: ID@XBOX can also provide access to Xbox One development kits for games that require access to the maximum potential of the Xbox One hardware.

segment.source: Will the standard Game engines work?
segment.target: Will the standard Game engines work?

segment.source: Check out the Known issues page for this preview release.
segment.target: Check out the Known issues page for this preview release.

segment.source: What capabilities and system resources are available to UWP games on Xbox One?
segment.target: What capabilities and system resources are available to UWP games on Xbox One?

segment.source: See System resources for UWP apps and games on Xbox One for information.
segment.target: See System resources for UWP apps and games on Xbox One for information.

segment.source: If I create a DirectX 12 UWP game, will it run on my Xbox One in Developer Mode?
segment.target: If I create a DirectX 12 UWP game, will it run on my Xbox One in Developer Mode?

segment.source: See System resources for UWP apps and games on Xbox One for information.
segment.target: See System resources for UWP apps and games on Xbox One for information.

segment.source: Will the entire UWP API surface be available on Xbox?
segment.target: Will the entire UWP API surface be available on Xbox?

segment.source: Check out the Known issues page for this preview release.
segment.target: Check out the Known issues page for this preview release.

segment.source: Fixing deployment failures
segment.target: Fixing deployment failures

segment.source: If you can’t deploy your app from Visual Studio, these steps may help you fix the problem.
segment.target: If you can’t deploy your app from Visual Studio, these steps may help you fix the problem.

segment.source: If you get stuck, ask for help on the forum.
segment.target: If you get stuck, ask for help on the forum.

segment.source: If Visual Studio cannot connect to your Xbox One:
segment.target: If Visual Studio cannot connect to your Xbox One:

segment.source: Make sure that you are in Developer Mode (discussed earlier on this page).
segment.target: Make sure that you are in Developer Mode (discussed earlier on this page).

segment.source: Make sure that you have set up your development PC correctly.
segment.target: Make sure that you have set up your development PC correctly.

segment.source: Did you follow all of the directions in Getting started with UWP app development on Xbox One?
segment.target: Did you follow all of the directions in Getting started with UWP app development on Xbox One?

segment.source: If you haven’t yet, read through the Development environment setup topic and the Introduction to Xbox One tools topic.
segment.target: If you haven’t yet, read through the Development environment setup topic and the Introduction to Xbox One tools topic.

segment.source: Make sure that you can “ping” your console IP address from your development PC.
segment.target: Make sure that you can “ping” your console IP address from your development PC.

segment.source: Note In order to get the best deployment performance, we recommend that you use a wired connection to your console.
segment.target: Note In order to get the best deployment performance, we recommend that you use a wired connection to your console.

segment.source: Make sure that you are using the Universal (Unencrypted Protocol) in the Authentication drop-down list on the Debug tab.
segment.target: Make sure that you are using the Universal (Unencrypted Protocol) in the Authentication drop-down list on the Debug tab.

segment.source: See Development environment setup for more details.
segment.target: See Development environment setup for more details.

segment.source: If I’m building an app using HTML/JavaScript, how do I enable Gamepad navigation?
segment.target: If I’m building an app using HTML/JavaScript, how do I enable Gamepad navigation?

segment.source: TVHelpers is a set of JavaScript and XAML/C# samples and libraries to help you build great Xbox One and TV experiences in JavaScript and C#.
segment.target: TVHelpers is a set of JavaScript and XAML/C# samples and libraries to help you build great Xbox One and TV experiences in JavaScript and C#.

segment.source: TVJS is a library that helps you build premium UWP apps for Xbox One.
segment.target: TVJS is a library that helps you build premium UWP apps for Xbox One.

segment.source: TVJS includes support for automatic controller navigation, rich media playback, search, and more.
segment.target: TVJS includes support for automatic controller navigation, rich media playback, search, and more.

segment.source: You can use TVJS with your hosted web app just as easily as with a packaged web UWP app with full access to the Windows Runtime APIs.
segment.target: You can use TVJS with your hosted web app just as easily as with a packaged web UWP app with full access to the Windows Runtime APIs.

segment.source: For more information see the TVHelpers project and the project wiki.
segment.target: For more information see the TVHelpers project and the project wiki.

segment.target: See also
